matt-SmartBear
2017-08-28 03:18:37

Thanks a lot for offering to get involved @mlvandijk. It’s worth explaining, I think, that Cucumber Ltd are paying @plaindocs, who’s a professional technical documentation writer, to do the migration on behalf of the community. His goal is to close down all those other sources like the wiki, cucumber.io/docs etc and move everything into one place. He’s almost done I think, but he’s been on vacation these past few weeks.

Once that migration is done and we have one set of docs, the work will begin to identify gaps in that documentation, or parts that need work. That’s where we’ll really need the community’s help.

I would suggest you keep in contact with @plaindocs just so you don’t double up your efforts.

What timezone are you in @mlvandijk? Maybe we can all have a call once @plaindocs is back from vacation and sync up?

This is (or at least used to be) really bad ruby, as it adds the is_it_friday? method to the global namespace. What we should be doing here is 

module FridayStepHelper
  def is_it_friday?(day)
  end
end
World FridayStepHelper

...

which is quite a bit more complicated.

luke
2018-04-23 09:45:15

The thing in Ruby with ParameterTypes, is they're definitely great going forwards. But I know a lot of people who are just "unlearning" transforms. I wouldn't put it in the 10min guide personally. Raw regex still works, and is still going to be supported going forwards. So something like alternation groups would be the quickest thing

Given(/^today is (Monday|Tuesday|Wednesday|Thursday|Friday|Saturday|Sunday$/) do - This also then shows someone a nice lead on to using the World / Helpers.

@Dana Scheider (they/he) You can find the Ruby version here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

CONTRIBUTING.md
<pre><code>## About to create a new Github Issue? We appreciate that. But before you do, please learn our basic rules: ** This is not a support forum. If you have a question, please go to [The Cukes Google Group](&lt;http://groups.google.com/group/cukes&gt;). ** Do you have an idea for a new feature? Then don't expect it to be implemented unless you or someone else sends a [pull request](&lt;https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests&gt;). You might be better to start a discussion on [the google group](&lt;http://groups.google.com/group/cukes&gt;). ** Reporting a bug? Please tell us: ** which version of Cucumber you're using ** which version of Ruby you're using. ** How to reproduce it. Bugs with a failing test in a [pull request](&lt;https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests&gt;) get fixed much quicker. Some bugs may never be fixed. ** Want to paste some code or output? Put \`\`\` on a line above and below your code/output. See [GFM](&lt;https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown&gt;)'s **Fenced Code Blocks** for details. ** We love [pull requests](&lt;https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests&gt;). But if you don't have a test to go with it we probably won't merge it. # Contributing to Cucumber The rest of this document is a guide for those maintaining Cucumber, and others who would like to submit patches. ## Talking with other devs You can chat with the core team on &lt;https://gitter.im/cucumber/contributors&gt;. We try to have office hours on Fridays. ## Installing your own gems A `Gemfile.local`-file can be used to have your own gems installed to support your normal development workflow. Example: ~~~ruby gem 'pry' gem 'pry-byebug' gem 'byebug' ~~~ ## Note on Patches/Pull Requests ** Fork the project. Make a branch for your change. ** Make your feature addition or bug fix. ** Make sure your patch is well covered by tests. We don't accept changes to Cucumber that aren't tested. ** Please do not change the Rakefile, version, or history. (if you want to have your own version, that is fine but bump version in a commit by itself so we can ignore when we merge your change) ** Send us a pull request. ## Running tests gem install bundler bundle install bundle exec rake To get code coverage results, run `bundle exec rake cov` ## First timer? No problem! If you are new to the project or to OSS, check the label [Easy](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/labels/Easy&gt;). Also, you can help us to correct style violations reported here: [.rubocop_todo.yaml](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/.rubocop_todo.yml&gt;). ## Release Process ** Bump the version number in `lib/cucumber/version`. ** Make sure `CHANGELOG.md` is updated with the upcoming version number, and has entries for all fixes. Now release it bundle update bundle exec rake git commit -m "Release X.Y.Z" # Make sure you run gem signin as the &lt;a href="mailto:cukebot@cucumber.io"&gt;cukebot@cucumber.io&lt;/a&gt; user before running the following step. Credentials can be found in 1Password rake release </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

#67 Document build/contributing process for contributors
<p><em>From <a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">@aslakhellesoy</a> on March 21, 2017 23:47</em></p> <p>It's a bit daunting for newcomers to find out where and how to make changes.</p> <p>• Do I contribute in monorepo or subrepo? • How do they get synced? • What directory? • How does CI work? • What software do I need? • How do I run a build on my machine? • How can I find issues to help on? • Where do I send pull requests? • When do I get commit rights? • Who's on the core team? • How do I make a release?</p> <p>There are some docs about this in the root folder (some of them are out of date). <code>CONTRIBUTING.md</code> is too long and boring.</p> <p>Let's steal shamelessly from these great projects (with credits):</p> <p>• <a href="http://hood.ie/contribute/">http://hood.ie/contribute/</a> • <a href="https://github.com/exercism/exercism.io/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">https://github.com/exercism/exercism.io/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md</a></p> <p>Some general guides for inspiration:</p> <p>• <a href="https://opensource.guide/">https://opensource.guide/</a> • <a href="http://www.firsttimersonly.com/">http://www.firsttimersonly.com/</a> • <a href="https://opensource.com/life/16/3/contributor-guidelines-template-and-tips">https://opensource.com/life/16/3/contributor-guidelines-template-and-tips</a> • <a href="https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/">https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/</a> • <a href="http://contribution-guide-org.readthedocs.io/#">http://contribution-guide-org.readthedocs.io/#</a> • <a href="http://www.writethedocs.org/guide/">http://www.writethedocs.org/guide/</a></p> <p><em>Copied from original issue: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/167">cucumber/cucumber#167</a></em></p>

Well that one is atleast easy to fix. : https://github.com/cucumber/docs.cucumber.io/pull/406

mpkorstanje (https://github.com/mpkorstanje)
#406 Use consistent tone in overview
<p>• Both the Gherkin and the Cucumber section follow the Q&amp;A pattern.<br /> For consistency the Step Definition section should follow this<br /> pattern. • Step Definition section referenced feature files. A concept not<br /> introduced prior. Change this to reference Gherkin steps in instead<br /> (which have been introduced before) • Diagram was missing. Added some ASCII art. • Removed snark regarding testing techniques. Lets assume that<br /> people who read this are tabulla rassa when it comes to Cucumber.<br /> The snark just isn't a good look here.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/docs.cucumber.io">cucumber/docs.cucumber.io</a>

matt-SmartBear
2020-01-06 04:39:38

Hello @Lisa Crispin! Sorry for the slow reply, I’ve been away from Slack for the holidays.

matt-SmartBear
2020-01-06 04:46:16

I would be so 🎉 to have your help with a process diagram for BDD. I love the diagrams in your books. The problem of trying to describe BDD in pictures is one I care about greatly and still don’t feel satisfied with our answers to.

I thought long and hard about the diagram we used in https://cucumber.io/docs/bdd/ and settled on this one which uses concentric feedback loops, inspired by the XP one. But this is by no means the definitive BDD diagram. The idea of that diagram is to just try and paint a picture of BDD and give people a sense of it, rather than provide step-by-step guidance.

I would like to see something in-between this one and Seb’s one. Seb’s one, while instructive, is maybe a bit overwhelming. It also includes activities that are not BDD activities themselves, just part of the context in which you do BDD.

Seb’s one from Linked-in also doesn’t use the terms we’re trying to standardise on: discover, formulate, and automate.

seb
2020-01-06 06:27:46

The LinkedIn diagram does incorporate Discovery/Formulation/Automation:

2 - Discovery

3 - Formulation

5 (and #6) - Automation

mlvandijk
2020-01-07 22:36:47

Also, there is a PR to update the docs to state that a Rule can have a background. The last I know is we decided against that at Cukenfest 2019 open source day. Did that change? (It may well have without me being aware of it). Just want to make sure before accepting/rejecting the PR to the docs.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-01-08 04:30:55

@mlvandijk we wanted to disallow Background in Rule, but it requires a change to the Berp parser generator which nobody has had the time to do, so it went stale: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/590

ciaranmcnulty (https://github.com/ciaranmcnulty)
#590 Gherkin: Remove Background from Rule in grammar
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Based on conversation at Cukenfest, we will take out Background from Rules and see if valid use cases emerge</p> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p>This will become a parse error:</p> <pre><code>Feature: My Feature Rule: My Rule Background: My background </code></pre> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <p>Currently backgrounds are inlined into the pickles created from the Scenarios</p>
Labels
Stale, library: gherkin, type: enhancement
Comments
7
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
mlvandijk
2020-01-08 05:36:54

Is it still what we want? In which case I would reject the PR to the docs.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-01-08 05:38:52

Background in Rule is currently supported, so the documentation should reflect that. We can change it if we ever fix issue 590

matt-SmartBear
2020-01-08 06:50:41

Maybe the docs should also reflect the fact that we don’t think it’s a good idea and might remove it in the future?

David Goss
2020-01-08 07:53:10

Is the rationale behind wanting to get rid of Rule-Background written up anywhere? I’m trying to think how I’ll provide an example (which is sort of an implicit endorsement) of something in a doc if we also think it’s an anti pattern

David Goss
2020-01-08 08:01:10

Thanks @Aslak Hellesøy - the PR is here btw https://github.com/cucumber/docs.cucumber.io/pull/440

davidjgoss (https://github.com/davidjgoss)
#440 update docs for Rule, regarding Background
<p>When implementing Rule support for JS in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1273">cucumber/cucumber-js#1273</a>, noticed that, per <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/cucumber-messages/messages.proto#L199">the messages spec</a>, a <code>Rule</code> can have a <code>Background</code>. The docs currently contradict this; looking at the history it has gone back and forth a bit, but latest update seems to be that it <em>is</em> supported.</p> <p>So this updates the section for <code>Background</code> to say it can be used under <code>Rule</code>. I've tried to provide some advice about when you might do that, which probably needs tweaking.</p> <p>Also:</p> <p>• Makes the warning about incomplete support in Cucumber implementations a more prominent message • ~Fixes a minor spacing issue with that message component~ now in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/docs.cucumber.io/pull/442">#442</a></p>

From that comment looks like I should definitely remove the sentence that says you can have background on both feature and rule in the same file - extra long rope!

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-01-08 08:03:04

You currently can have Background under Rule because we weren't able to disallow it easily using the current parser. We'd like to deprecate/remove that ability, but the docs should reflect what's possible today, even if it's not what we want.

Not at all - I think we should tell people it's currently possible, but we strongly discourage using it because: a) It will be a mess b) It may be removed

#833 Update direct links to docs on Cucumber website
<p><strong>👓 What did you see?</strong></p> <p>Since adding the Cucumber docs to the SmartBear site, there is a menu option "Docs" that offers several links to the actual docs:</p> <p>• The arrow &gt; goes to <a href="https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/">https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/</a> - which is a good place to start • Installation • Gherkin Syntax • API Docs -> goes to API automation tools that are not Cucumber • 3rd Party Tools -> goes to tools that for the most part are not cucumber.</p> <p>I think nr 4 and 5 should not be part of this high level menu. We tried to fix this previously in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/docs/issues/433">#433</a> but this seems to have been reverted or overwritten.</p> <p><strong>✅ What did you expect to see?</strong></p> <p>Instead of links to API Docs and 3rd Party Tools, which are both <em>not</em> cucumber, we should provide direct links to relevant pages.<br /> Possibly the API Docs intended to link to <a href="https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/">https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/</a> which would be more useful.</p> <p>In addition, direct links to the 10 Minute Tutorial and Guides would help users find the information they need more quickly.</p> <p><strong>📦 Which tool/library version are you using?</strong></p> <p>N/A</p> <p><strong>🔬 How could we reproduce it?</strong></p> <p>Go to <a href="https://cucumber.io/">https://cucumber.io/</a> and click the <strong>Docs</strong> menu</p> <p><strong>📚 Any additional context?</strong></p> <p>As discussed in weekly committers meeting on Jan 19th 2023.</p>
